nodes.text:
Congratulations on a successful deployment against the [[DM.Factions[faction_TaurianConcordat],Taurians]], Commander.

We should discuss what happened on Smithon, and where we're heading next.

branches.responseText: I'd like to discuss the state of our war against the Directorate.
Tell me about yourself, Lord Madeira.
I should go. We'll talk later, Lord Madeira.

nodes.text:
As I said, your victory on Smithon was nothing short of inspirational. You stopped the Taurian assault in its tracksâ€”even forced them to withdraw.

Such skill deserves all the praise I can offer, and then some. You've done the impossible. Know it.

branches.responseText: It's a little premature to celebrate, Lord Madeira. The ship that we drove away is probably on its way to do the same thing to some other Restoration system.
Ostergaard has a personal vendetta against Kamea. How are we going to deal with him?
I've heard all I need, Lord Madeira. Let's talk about something else.

nodes.text: You're right. It probably is, and we can do nothing to stop it. We're going to lose people to the Taurians, Commander {COMMANDER.LastName}. A lot of people. And money, and infrastructure, and whatever else you care to mention. At this point, the losses are inevitable.

Still, we should celebrate our small victories where we find them. You have driven the Taurians away from one of our systems. That's downright heroic. And at this point of the war, our people need heroes, so I'd advise you to accept their praise for what it is.
So long as he stays on his ship, we can't. The Iberia is a Fortress-class DropShip. Even if we could bait it into landing, it'd blow your lance to pieces before you even got into weapons range.

If I were in your place, I'd take it as a given that we can't defeat Ostergaard. He'll hound us until Kamea is dead or he is called home. And so, that's how we proceed. We don't defeat Ostergaard, we survive him. And when [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreAnaMariaCentrella],Lady Centrella]] provides us with a way to remove the Taurians from the war, we have him called back home.

It isn't an ideal solution, I know. I'd be more satisfied killing the bastard, myself.

But it's a plan, and I think it will work. That's the best we can do, given the circumstances.

Commander {COMMANDER.LastName}. These are dark days for the Restoration, but I have faith that your company will see us through.

If there's something I can do for you, name it. I'll do what I can to provide.

branches.responseText: I'd like to discuss the state of our war against the Directorate.
Tell me about yourself, Lord Madeira.
I should go. We'll talk later, Lord Madeira.

nodes.text:
It progresses, but at great cost. The [[DM.Factions[faction_TaurianConcordat],Taurian Concordat]] has introduced a great deal of uncertainty into what was already a nightmare of a campaign.

At least we still have [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreAnaMariaCentrella],Lady Centrella]] working on our side. Without the Magistracy's support, we'd be lost.

branches.responseText: Lady Arano seems to be hinging a lot on my company. It sounded like she intends to throw us against Ostergaard.
You saw what Ostergaard did to Lord Karosas. How are we supposed to stop him from doing that again?
I've heard all I need, Lord Madeira. Let's talk about something else.

nodes.text: Yes, but surgically and sparingly, to deflect the Taurians. Not to destroy them. We'll see how that works after you deploy on Smithon. For what it's worth, I'll be rooting for you.

We can't. All we can do is warn the other [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreFoundingHouses],Founding Houses]] and tell them to stay on the move. Ostergaard is a butcher, but he can't be everywhere at once. As formidable as the Iberia is, she's only one ship, and the Periphery is a big place.

It's a situation that can't last foreverâ€¦ but with luck, it won't have to. As Lady Centrella said, her people are looking for a way through this.

I have faith that they'll find it eventually. All we need to worry about is surviving until they do.

It's good that you've come to me, Commander {COMMANDER.LastName}. What happened on Artru will change everything.

You need to be prepared.

branches.responseText: I'd like to discuss the state of our war against the Directorate.
Tell me about yourself, Lord Madeira.
I should go. We'll talk later, Lord Madeira.

nodes.text:
The [[DM.Factions[faction_TaurianConcordat],Taurian Concordat]] is fighting on the Directorate's behalf. That wasn't supposed to happen.

It's our job to figure out how we're going to keep moving forward now that it has.

I've sent a coded message to Lord Karosas informing him of recent events, and of our suspicions regarding his son.

I've recommended that he have Otto confined to the palace and placed under guardâ€”for his own protection, mind. None of this his his fault.

As far as the Restoration is concerned: obviously, we're in trouble. But I'm fairly confident that [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreAnaMariaCentrella],Lady Centrella]] will help us find a solution.

That sounds like wishful thinking, I know. But [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreHouseCentrella],House Centrella]] has a vested interest in our success. The last thing they want is a Taurian proxy expanding toward [[DM.Factions[faction_MagistracyOfCanopus],Canopian]] space, and that's what the Directorate appears to have become.

For our part, we move forward, no matter what. Not out of pride, but because we have to. This war isn't some meaningless [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreInnerSphere],Inner Sphere]] pissing contest. It's a struggle for the spirit of the Aurigan people. Surrender isn't an option, and neither is flight. We will find a way to prevail, because we have to. There is no other option.

Commander. I have preparations to make for our trip to Artru, but I can make time for you if you need me.

How can I be of help?

branches.responseText: I'd like to discuss the state of our war against the Directorate.
Tell me about yourself, Lord Madeira.
I should go. We'll talk later, Lord Madeira.

nodes.text:
It's in a state of flux. If we find what we're looking for on Artru, the entire face of the war could change. There are no guarantees, of course, but I'm optimistic.

In Kamea's eyes, this is one step removed from prophecyâ€”her father's stories and predictions come to life.

branches.responseText: Strange that she's so interested in the Star League. The SLDF brutalized the Periphery.
What do you think we're going to find on Artru?
I guess we'll see what happens when we get there. Let's talk about something else.

nodes.text:
That's true. The [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreStarLeague],Star League]] was abusive and cruel to our people, and the [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreAmarisCivilWar],Amaris Civil War]] was a direct result.

Kamea knows all of this as well as anyone. As did her father.

Lady Arano isn't trying to revive the Star League's culture. She doesn't blindly worship their decadence and callousnessâ€¦ not as those in the [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreInnerSphere],Inner Sphere]] do. When she was a child, perhaps, but not anymore. What she's after is their technologyâ€”the tools they used to oppress us, once upon a time. And she will turn those tools to our purpose, for the good of the Reach.

Honestly? I can't say. Perhaps we'll find the armory full of BattleMechs that Dr. Murad alluded to, or a functional [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreMemoryCore],Memory Core]] full of Star Leagueâ€“era secrets and technology. Or maybe we'll find nothing at all.

One thing I can tell you for certain: there isn't a government in the Peripheryâ€”or the Inner Sphere, for that matterâ€”that wouldn't strip Artru bare to claim Castle Nautilus. It's a damned lucky thing we're getting there first.

You did well on Anvelt, Commander. As always, the Restoration offers its appreciation for your expertise on the battlefield.

Now, tell meâ€¦ what can I do for you?

branches.responseText: I'd like to discuss the state of our war against the Directorate.
Tell me about yourself, Lord Madeira.
I should go. We'll talk later, Lord Madeira.

nodes.text:
And Lady Victoria, I imagine.

I do hope she's enjoying her new accommodations. She's finally where she belongs.

branches.responseText: What's your long-term plan for dealing with her?
I've heard all I need, Lord Madeira. Let's talk about something else.

nodes.text:
Incarceration until the war is over. Then a public trial, with a jury drawn from what's left of the [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreFoundingCouncil],Founding Council]].

Given how the Directorate treated the [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreFoundingHouses],Founding Houses]] on Weldry, I imagine that deliberations will be short.

As to what happens after the guilty verdict comes inâ€¦ well, that's for Director Espinosa to decide.

If the Directorate surrenders without bloodshed, Kamea may be persuaded to let her cousin live in captivity. There's a prison on Hastur II that seems appropriateâ€¦ Victoria can grow old and die in exile, on the edge of the Frontier. There's a certain poetry to that.

â€¦Of course, there's always the possibility that her father won't surrender. That he'll force us to pay for every step we take as we march on Cordia City. In that case, I can't imagine that the Founding Houses will feel inclined to show mercy. Death by firing squad or beheading are the traditional methods of execution. She'll have earned her fate, either way.

Welcome back, Commander {COMMANDER.LastName}.

Is there something the Restoration can do for you?

branches.responseText: I'd like to discuss the state of our war against the Directorate.
Tell me about yourself, Lord Madeira.
I should go. We'll talk later, Lord Madeira.

nodes.text:
In the eyes of the public, the war is going well. We've liberated a second [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreFoundingHouses],Founding House]]. All across the Reach, people can feel the tide beginning to turnâ€¦ that's good news for our recruitment efforts.

Between you and me, we'll need those recruits. The Directorate made us pay dearly for our advance, and the strength of arms they're marshaling in their core systems worries me.

With luck, all of this bloodshed will come to justify itselfâ€¦ inspired by our struggle, our ranks will swell with volunteers, who will in turn inspire more Aurigans to break ranks with the Directorate and join the fight. That's what I'm working with now. The hope that our war machine will grow to the point where it can feed itself.

branches.responseText: What does the liberation of House Karosas mean for the Restoration?
"Feed itself," huh? Sounds a little ominous when you put it like that.
I've heard all I need, Lord Madeira. Let's talk about something else.

nodes.text:
As before, there are logistical advantages to breaking the Directorate's hold over swathes of the Reach.

Using systems like Smithon as staging areas, we can push deeperâ€”closer to Coromodir and the throneâ€”without risk of being cut off.

In addition, [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreHouseKarosas],House Karosas]] is renowned for the skill of its engineers and technologists. Bringing them to our side will provide great advantages in terms of keeping our DropShip fleet in repair.

This is a civil war, Commander. In fighting the Directorate, we are killing our own people. There's nothing about this that isn't ominous. I wish that it wasn't necessary for us to wage war at all, but sadly, Espinosa has made it so.

Commander {COMMANDER.LastName}, the Hero of Panzyr. A pleasure, as always.

Is there something I can do for you?

branches.responseText: I'd like to discuss the state of our war against the Directorate.
Tell me about yourself, Lord Madeira.
I should go. We'll talk later, Lord Madeira.

nodes.text:
Thanks to your efforts, the Restoration Army's push on the capital was a success. In a single stroke, we've liberated [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreHouseDecimis],House Decimis]], stripped away a fifth of Espinosa's power base, and shattered the illusion of a unified Directorate.

While our victory was complete, it didn't come without cost. We lost a lot of good soldiers on Panzyr, and several dozen irreplaceable BattleMechs. It'll take time to replenish our depleted ranks.

Beyond the scope of our recent victory, things are murkier. Thanks to the [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LorePerditionMassacre],Perdition Massacre]], tensions between the [[DM.Factions[faction_TaurianConcordat],Taurians]] and the [[DM.Factions[faction_Davion],Federated Suns]] have risen to a boiling point.

The situation is fraughtâ€¦ terribly so. The slightest misstep by either side could spell disaster, for us and for the rest of the [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreRimwardPeriphery],Rimward Periphery]].

branches.responseText: What does the liberation of House Decimis mean for the Restoration?
Let's talk about the Perdition Massacre.
I've heard all I need, Lord Madeira. Let's talk about something else.

nodes.text: A great deal. On a symbolic level, the liberation of a [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreFoundingHouses],Founding House]] may be the most important step we've taken since Weldry. Make no mistake, the other Founding Families were watching what was happening on Panzyr. If House Decimis could be liberated from Directorate control, then so could the rest of them. And now they know it.

There are logistical benefits as well, of course. The traditional seat of House Decimis is Panzyr, but its sphere of influence extends into Ryans Fate, Bringdam, and Mechdur. And now that House Decimis is our ally, we can start turning the people, facilities, and industrial bases of those systems against the Directorate.

An army lives or dies by its supply train, and ours has just gotten strongerâ€”at the Directorate's expense. And this is only the beginning.
I don't know much more than what Lady Arano's already told youâ€¦ but still, ask me your questions. I'll do whatever I can to answer them.

branches.responseText: Why would the Federated Suns attack the Taurian Concordat?
Why would anyone target Perdition specifically?
What are the odds that this incident pushes the Taurians to declare war all by itself?
Let's talk about something else.

nodes.text:
There's no proof that they haveâ€”only conjecture.

Speaking hypothetically, though? I can come up with a number of reasons.

Perhaps the [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreHouseDavion],Davions]] want to punish [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreHouseCalderon],House Calderon]] for some perceived transgression. Or maybe they want the Taurians to fly off the handle and declare war. Then they could stage an invasion of the Concordat while claiming self-defense. [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreHanseDavion],First Prince Hanse Davion]] is no stranger to international brinksmanship, or to the use of unpredictable tactics. He isn't called "The Fox" for nothing.

That said, [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreThomasCalderon],Protector Thomas Calderon's]] distrust of House Davion is equally well known. Some have gone so far as to claim that his fear of the "perfidious Davions" borders on obsession.

It's difficult to know how much of this is truth, and how much of it is hysteria.

What we do know is that something happened on Perdition, and that it cost eleven thousand Taurian civilians their lives. Calderon is calling it a Federation attack, and House Davion's denials have been dismissive and condescending. It's an ugly situation that's likely to get uglier. That is where things stand.

Because it's a symbol of Taurian independence. The destruction of an [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreSLDF],SLDF]] base on Perdition was what incited the Taurian Concordat to withdraw from the [[DM.BaseDescriptionDefs[LoreStarLeague],Star League]].

As a symbolic target, it'd be hard to do much better.

That's doubtful. Protector Calderon isn't stupid; he knows what open war with the Federated Suns would cost. And should he ever forget, there are cooler heads in the room to remind him.

His son, Edward, has been a particular help in that regard. We'd be in much worse shape without his influence.

For now, the Taurians are standing on the precipice of a conflict that none of us are prepared for.

But without another inciting incident, they're unlikely to step over the edge.
Of course, Commander {COMMANDER.LastName}. Whatever you need.

Commander {COMMANDER.LastName}. Welcome to my corner of the Command Center. From here, I can provide Mr. Oliveira with advice and information whenever he needs it.

I want to be a resource for you as well. In keeping with my role as Restoration liaison, I will give you whatever additional information I can about our campaign moving forward. Come see me after any major operation and I'll share whatever I can.

branches.responseText: I'd like to discuss the state of our war against the Directorate.
You're new on this crew. So tell me about yourself.
I should go. We'll talk later, Lord Madeira.

nodes.text:
Things are going well enough, Commander. Our initial attack on Weldry was an enormous success, despite the psychological costs of what we discovered there.

Still, the Directorate's atrocities have steeled our resolve. I've never seen Lady Arano so determined.

Out of curiosity, Commander {COMMANDER.LastName}â€¦ what did you think of her speech?

I recorded it, you know. The broadcasts are on their way to every corner of Directorate space.

branches.responseText: It was good. She said what the people wanted to hear. You think they bought it?
It sounded raw. From the heart. Mastiff would've been proud.
What you're saying is that you turned her speech into a PR stunt.

nodes.text: Hopefully. She meant every word she said. You're right to raise the question, thoughâ€¦ Espinosa's propaganda machine will do everything in its power to tarnish our accomplishments and drag us through the dirt. I can imagine the headlines now. "Police and civil servants cut down by weapons of war! Dangerous convicts set loose by a traitor, endangering nobles and commoners alike!" A dangerous narrative, and one that we'll have to counter at every turn.

With luck, many of our people will believe what they've heard in our broadcast over the Directorate's propaganda. But I fear that Espinosa's hard-line supporters will be far less eager to listen.

If we fail to turn them against the Directorate, we run the risk of ongoing violence, even after we liberate their home systems. That's why messages like Kamea's speech are so important.

branches.responseText: Espinosa's supporters just saw the conditions on Weldry with their own eyes. You don't think that'll be enough to sway them?
If the Directorate is using propaganda, we need some of our own. Got it.

nodes.text:
Some will be moved by our message, yes. But others will continue to embrace the Directorate's lies. These are people who've benefited from Espinosa's policies; they won't jump to condemn a system that has made them wealthy, and they won't want to feel complicit in its crimes.

Capturing their loyalty will be a long, hard battle. We won't win it overnight.

Sadly, yes. If we're going to win this war, we need to rally the Aurigan peopleâ€”including a percentage of Espinosa's supporters. They have to see that we're better than the Directorate, again and again, until our message is impossible to ignore. For you, that means military victories. For me, it means more broadcasts, spin, and outreach. Public opinion is just another battlefield, and I'll be knee-deep in the trenches until the day I die.

Good. That's what I was hoping to hear. The presumption of authenticity will carry us far.

For what it's worth, Lady Arano meant every word she said, but the people may not see it that way. Espinosa's propaganda machine will do everything in its power to tarnish our accomplishments and drag us through the dirt.

I can imagine the headlines now. "Police and civil servants cut down by weapons of war! Dangerous convicts set loose by a traitor, endangering nobles and commoners alike!" A dangerous narrative, and one that we'll have to counter at every turn.

I used it to control the narrative, {COMMANDER.LastName}. If I hadn't, Espinosa's propaganda apparatus most certainly would have. I can imagine the headlines now. "Police and civil servants cut down by weapons of war! Dangerous convicts set loose by a traitor, endangering nobles and commoners alike!" Better that the people of the Reach hear our version of events, don't you think?

I'd be happy to, butâ€¦

Honestly, Commander? I've been so consumed with matters of war of late that I wouldn't even know where to begin.

branches.responseText: Tell me about who you were before Kamea's exile and the Restoration.
Tell me about Guldra. What kind of world is it?
Let's talk about something else.

nodes.text:
A noble scionâ€¦ much the same as you were, from what I understand.

As a fellow noble, I'm sure that you already know more than most about my upbringing. It was a life of great privilege, and even greater expectation.

I spent my early years invested in academic pursuits: the study of history, mathematics, and statecraft. I strove to excel at every subjectâ€¦ anything to avoid disappointing my mother and father. The extent to which they would come to disappoint me is a cruel irony, but it's one that I've come to accept.

branches.responseText: What kind of expectations did you have to meet?
Must be hard to have your own parents betray you.
I'm sorry to hear it, Lord Madeira. Let's talk about something else.

nodes.text:
Do you know House Madeira's motto? "Behold Our Splendor." I had a familial obligation to live extravagantly, and to do so within the public eye. But I was also expected to develop my intellect.

My life was a fifty-fifty split between carousing and academic study. In truth, it felt like I was leading two livesâ€”and putting on a show in both. But I'll never complain about my upbringing. I have enjoyed advantages that most children of the Periphery could only dream of.

Oh, it is. Nothing could be harder.

When Kamea retakes her throne, there will be a reckoning, and Directorate collaborators will be tried for their crimes. My mother and father will be at the front of that list. And as terrible as it feels to say it, they'll deserve whatever punishment they receive.

Your apologies are unnecessaryâ€”by any metric you care to mention, I've lived a charmed life. The hardships of the past three years don't erase the lifetime of privilege I enjoyed before Espinosa's coup. It would be dishonest of me to pretend that they did.

But still, I am happy to change the subject if you wish.

A truly beautiful one. You should really travel there sometime after all of this is over and see it for yourself.

Imagine lush, green lowlands giving way to mile upon mile of white-sand coastline. Sandy beaches kissed by warm, salty seas, and soft rain perfumed with saffron and cardamom. And that's not to mention the wildlife.

Close your eyes and imagine it, Commander.

Shield terns wheeling and soaring, their brilliant plumage glittering in the sunlight. Leviathan sablefish flashing silver beneath the waves. Dolphinfish leaping, breaching the surface of the water in riotous streaks of yellow and green.

Places like Guldra are special, Commander {COMMANDER.LastName}. They must be preserved. This is what we're fighting for: something unspoiled, and unique, and ours. Something that reminds us how good the Periphery can be.
Of course, Commander {COMMANDER.LastName}. What do you need?
